learning_outcomes.description: Apply key principles and procedures of leadership as it can be applied in a rural and regional context
Apply the dynamics of personal attributes in leadership
Apply leadership in a group, industry and community context, and be able to practise leadership effectively in at least one of these contexts
Demonstrate the ability to manage issues that arise in leadership such as manage conflict, foster the development of teams, mentor others, create collective vision etc.
Demonstrate the ability to sustain leadership functions in groups and in other settings
Demonstrate the skills and processes to learn from experience and learn collaboratively

assessments.assessment_title: Learning project plan and personal learning goals
assessments.task_description:
The Learning Project Plan is your comprehensive action plan for the experiential learning project you will carry out during the semester. It focuses on addressing a leadership challenge within the context of the group literature review project and setting personal leadership development goals. This assessment integrates the first three steps of the experiential learning cycle:

  • Reflection on the Situation: Identify and analyze a leadership challenge. This is often something that you have struggled with in the past in group settings —for example, fostering collaboration, managing conflict, or ensuring equitable participation.
  • Generalisation: Use leadership theories to formulate your leadership goals and objectives.
  • Planned Action: Design a practical plan for demonstrating leadership in the group project and achieving your personal leadership goals.

Your Learning Project Plan should include:

  • A reflection on the importance of leadership in your professional or personal context, particularly in group settings.
  • Examples of leadership aspects you find enjoyable, challenging, or intimidating, especially in collaborative environments.
  • A description of the leadership challenge you anticipate.
  • Leadership concepts and skills you aim to develop and apply.
  • Planned actions and strategies for demonstrating leadership, ensuring the focus is on leadership (not management or administration).
  • 3–5 SMART personal learning goals, focusing on the leadership skills or qualities you want to develop during your learning project.

This integrated approach helps you align the general topic of leadership with your personal interests and ensures your development goals are clear, actionable, and relevant to the your context.

Word Limit: 1,000 words (excluding references).


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, on Blackboard, via the link provided by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.weighting: <dd>50% Each test contributes 10% towards the total progressive assessment value of 50% </dd>

Module 2 3/04/2025

Module 3 17/04/2025

Module 4 8/05/2025

Module 5 22/05/2025

Assessment will be conducted in class, during the first hour of the workshop.
assessments.task_description:
Each module ends with a timed in-class, online test (30 minutes), comprising of short essay questions where you will be asked to apply leadership theories to a real-world scenario. The test will occur at the beginning of the relevant workshop. All module tests are equally weighted.

Students will need to bring their own fully charged and reliable electronic device to the workshops to complete these module tests.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The online assessment is completed within Blackboard under the appropriate assessment title on your course Blackboard site. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.  

Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in-person. 

Students will write a structured reflection based on course experiences using Kolb’s Experiential Learning Cycle.

The exam will be open-book (students can bring their course notes and prior journal entries if applicable).

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
